ANSWER.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Social Security has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) One.
(2) The Commissioner for Employees' Compensation.

(3) The function of the Commissioner under the Compensation (Commonwealth Government Employees) Act 1971 is to determine matters and questions arising under the Act. Where a determination by the Commissioner is made under the Act, an application may be made to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal for a review of the determination by or on behalf of a party to the determination. No other person may make such an application, and there are no appeal mechanisms available to the general public to lodge a complaint against the Commissioner. The Commonwealth Ombudsman may also investigate complaints concerning the administration of the Compensation (Commonwealth Government Employees) Act 1971.

(4) None. However, the Governor-General may terminate the appointment of the Commissioner for inefficiency, misbehaviour or physical or mental incapacity. The officers of the Australian Public Service employed in the Office of the Commissioner are officers of the Department of Social Security and are subject to normal disciplinary procedures under the Public Service Act and Regulations.

In addition, the Attorney-General's Department has advised that, unless an authority is statutorily protected, it is liable for the torts of its servants committed in the course of their duty. Where employees, acting in the course of their duty are incompetent and, as a consequence, loss is suffered by a member of the public, it will commonly be found that the act or omission which was seen as incompetent was also tortious. For example, incompetent driving would probably be tortious. In the absence of a denial of liability the negligent giving of erroneous advice is tortious where the advice is given by a person having a duty of care to one who suffers foreseeable damage as a result of reasonably relying on that advice. Many other forms of incompetence would also be tortious, but each case would need to be considered on its own facts. The Commissioner for Employees' Compensation is not statutorily protected against general liability in tort.

(5) As at 31 December 1985, 147 applications for review of a determination of the Commissioner were before the Administrative Appeals Tribunal. The Tribunal lists all applications for review of the Commissioner's determination for hearing within 28 weeks of the date of application. In practice, however, a matter is often settled by agreement between the parties involved before the date of hearing. In some cases hearings are delayed as a result of difficulties in securing appointments with medical specialists and other expert witnesses.
(6) The Commissioner for Employees' Compensation can be sued.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Qantas Airways Ltd: Flight Guide Maps

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Puplick Sen C.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 18 March 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Do consultations take place between the appropriate Officers of the Department of Foreign Affairs and Qantas, concerning the depiction of international boundaries of the flight guide maps published by Qantas in its ``Inflight'' magazine; if so, do the boundaries of Israel currently portrayed by Qantas on its maps represent the policy of the Australian Government.

(2) If no consultations are held and/or the boundaries for the state of Israel do not represent those acknowledged by policy of successive Australian Governments, will appropriate steps be taken to ensure that an appropriate depiction is made.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Foreign Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) I assume the honourable senator is referring to the March/April 1986 edition of the Qantas magazine Airways. The depiction of Israel on the map in the edition is so small that it is not possible to determine with any accuracy where its boundaries are drawn. The map identifies Tel Aviv and Jerusalem. Although there is no legend to the map, Jerusalem is marked in a way which could be taken as indicating that it is the capital of Israel.

Consultations do not take place between officers of the Department of Foreign Affairs and Qantas concerning the depiction of international boundaries or other features on Qantas flight guide maps. I am advised that Qantas' magazine Airways is produced under contract to a private publisher.

(2) The boundaries of Israel recognised under Australian Government policy do not include Jerusalem as the capital of Israel or the territories occupied by Israel in 1967. The Australian Government does not recognise the law passed by the Israeli Knesset in July 1980 which declared Jerusalem, including East Jerusalem, to be the undivided capital of Israel. Nor does it recognise the annexation of the Golan Heights in 1981.

I would also note that the map contains a number of other inaccuracies. In respect of Africa the map identifies the so-called `independent homelands' of Bophuthatswana, Venda, Transkei and Kwazulu, as separate States. Neither Australia nor any other member of the international community accords recognition to the so-called homelands as independent States. The map also needs to reflect the fact that Upper Volta is now called Burkino Faso. I will arrange to have these matters and other minor inaccuracies drawn to the attention of Qantas.
